issues.description: The UML in the problem statement marks the Animal constructor as private ( '-' before 'Animal(String)' ), which contradicts the intended design and the solution. Subclasses (Seal, Pig, Goat) must call super(name) to initialize the name and therefore need access to the Animal constructor. The solution implements a public Animal(String) constructor, and the example usage in Main constructs Seal/Pig/Goat instances. If students follow the UML literally, a private constructor would prevent correct subclassing and make implementing the exercise impossible.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the UML in problem_statement.md so the Animal(String) constructor is accessible to subclasses. Change the visibility marker from '-' (private) to '+' (public) or to '#' (protected) in the UML. Update any textual description if required to state that subclasses can call super(name).

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement shows Farm.addAnimal(Animal) with a private visibility marker ('-'), while the exercise text, the template Main usage, and the solution treat addAnimal as a public method. If students follow the UML literally and implement addAnimal as private, they will not be able to add animals from outside the Farm (e.g., from Main), which contradicts the usage examples and intended API.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML in problem_statement.md to mark addAnimal(Animal) as public ('+'). Ensure the written task text and UML are consistent by explicitly stating that addAnimal is part of the public API so callers (e.g., Main) can add animals to the farm.
